prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We require single continuum observations in Band 7 with the maximum bandwidth of 7.5 GHz and 2-GHz for each baseband centered at 336.5, 338.5, 348.5 and 350.5 GHz.

All sources are unresolved which means that the resolution setup within the Band 7 limits should not affect the observations as no extended emission is expected to be observed. We propose a compact configuration with a resolution of 0.98 arcsec
We require a continuum sensitivity limit of 0.15 mJy. In this case, the source should be detected at the >5-sigma level
We require single continuum observations in Band 7 with the maximum bandwidth of 7.5 GHz and 2-GHz for each baseband centered at 336.5, 338.5, 348.5 and 350.5 GHz.

All sources are unresolved which means that the resolution setup within the Band 7 limits should not affect the observations as no extended emission is expected to be observed. We propose a compact configuration with a resolution of 0.98 arcsec, appropriate for all sources
We require a continuum sensitivity limit of 0.15 mJy. In this case, the source should be detected at the >5-sigma level

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: High redshift AGN are key targets for studies of the formation and evolution of galaxies. The role of dust in these processes and the affect of the AGN activity are uncertain. We propose to study the dust continuum emission for the largest X-ray AGN sample to-date at z>3 (C-COSMOS & ChaMP), requesting ALMA Band 7 continuum observations for the 40/87 ChaMP AGN visible by ALMA. SCUBA-2 observations are in hand for the C-COSMOS sub-sample while a SCUBA-2 observation programm for the remaining ChAMP AGN is in progress. Submillimeter observations of the total sample are crucial for covering a wide range of AGN properties which is impossible using only C-COSMOS due to its small survey area. Understanding the AGN/host galaxy interplay at z>3 is crucial since it corresponds to the era of the first growth and formation of SMBHs.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
